item.content:encoded: […] the EU working with China and the US, as well as Latin America and Africa, on these issues?” asked palaeontologist and open-access campaigner Jon Tennant in a blog post shortly after the plan was announced. “There is the opportunity to coordinate […]

item.title: By: Federico Leva
item.dc:creator: Federico Leva
item.description:
I don't understand where you see a "focus on APC-driven Open Access". As Peter Suber has commented, Plan S has the merit of welcoming both green and gold OA. The requirements it sets out for immediate OA can be satisfied by green OA if all else fails.
The explicit mention of the need to fund "Open Access Infrastructure" also sounds to me like good news for all green OA repositories, university and consortium-led fully OA journals, more experimental open science platforms and so on, which have the potential to grow very quickly if given a chance.
item.content:encoded:
I don’t understand where you see a “focus on APC-driven Open Access”. As Peter Suber has commented, Plan S has the merit of welcoming both green and gold OA. The requirements it sets out for immediate OA can be satisfied by green OA if all else fails.

The explicit mention of the need to fund “Open Access Infrastructure” also sounds to me like good news for all green OA repositories, university and consortium-led fully OA journals, more experimental open science platforms and so on, which have the potential to grow very quickly if given a chance.
